topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Scott shares how Cognition’s 15-engineer team uses Devin internally, with Devin generating ~25% of PRs today and an expectation of >50% by year-end. Lenny introduces Scott, Cognition, and the episode’s focus on the future of software engineering with AI agents.

topics.title: Sponsor Break: Enterpret and Paragon
topics.summary: Two sponsor segments: Enterpret (customer feedback analysis with AI models) and Paragon (building and maintaining integrations for AI products).

topics.title: What Devin is and how it works
topics.summary: Scott defines Devin as a fully autonomous, asynchronous software engineer that can be assigned tasks via Slack/Linear and produces GitHub pull requests. The emphasis is on fitting into real team workflows like a junior remote engineer.

topics.title: Devin’s evolution: capabilities and product interface
topics.summary: They compare Devin’s “seniority” from early days to now (from student/intern to junior engineer), noting jagged intelligence. Scott highlights that progress came both from better models and from workflow features like integrations, planning, and code touch-ups.

topics.title: Adoption and use cases across company sizes
topics.summary: Scott describes Devin’s usage from tiny startups to Fortune 100s, with different engineering contexts but a common theme of speed and leverage. He also notes Devin can accumulate team knowledge and reuse it across sessions.

topics.title: Origin story: team background and early thesis
topics.summary: Scott explains how the founding team (with backgrounds like Lunchclub, Scale AI, Cursor) came together in late 2023. Their core beliefs: reinforcement learning would drive a capability leap, code is ideal due to fast feedback loops, and products would shift from text completion to autonomous agents.

topics.title: Hacker-house pivots and finding the agent workflow
topics.summary: Scott recounts iterative “hacker house” development, starting with contest programming agents and evolving into a software engineering agent. Key learnings included making Devin interactive (planning, mid-course corrections) rather than purely handoff-and-return.

topics.title: Why personify Devin: name, onboarding, and trust
topics.summary: They discuss the deliberate choice to give the agent a name and treat it like a junior teammate to guide user expectations. Scott explains onboarding patterns (start small, set up repo/VM, teach the agent) and the value of asynchronous collaboration.

topics.title: How engineering work changes with Devin today
topics.summary: Scott frames software engineering as instructing computers and argues it becomes more important as AI improves. He shares internal metrics (hundreds of Devin PRs/month; ~25% of PRs) and describes a workflow where humans handle the critical 10–20% while Devin executes the rest.

topics.title: From bricklayer to architect: future skill shifts
topics.summary: Scott predicts Devin-written PRs will exceed 50% by year-end and argues the core of engineering is problem definition and architecture, not boilerplate and debugging toil. They discuss learning to code, the importance of fundamentals/abstractions, and which skills grow in value (systems thinking, trade-offs, product context).

topics.title: Jevons Paradox and why engineers may increase
topics.summary: Scott explains Jevons Paradox and applies it to software: as coding gets cheaper/faster, total software built (and demand for builders) can rise rather than fall. He expects more programmers overall and more personalized software experiences.

topics.title: Managing a fleet: five Devins per engineer
topics.summary: Scott describes Cognition’s internal practice of running up to ~5 Devins per engineer in parallel to maximize asynchronous throughput. They discuss the learning curve and why agentic workflows unlock larger productivity gains than simple code completion.

topics.title: Live demo: Devin adds a website feature
topics.summary: Scott kicks off a real-time task to modify the Devin web app to feature Lenny’s newsletter, showing Devin’s planning questions and how humans can steer decisions (e.g., open link in new tab). The segment highlights synchronous vs asynchronous collaboration and mid-task guidance.

topics.title: Demo: Devin researches and builds a quiz app
topics.summary: Scott shows a playback where Devin researches Lenny (web browsing) and then builds a small quiz website to help Scott prep for the interview. They briefly run through quiz questions, illustrating agentic research-to-app creation.

topics.title: Demo: Devin Wiki for codebase understanding
topics.summary: Scott demonstrates Devin’s auto-generated wiki/index of a GitHub repo (DeepSeek), including architecture pages and Q&A over the codebase. The focus is on how codebase representations help both Devin and humans during scoping and development.

topics.title: Sponsor Break: Attio
topics.summary: Lenny begins a sponsor read for Attio, an AI-native CRM that auto-builds a CRM from email/calendar and supports flexible data syncing and enrichment.
